text: hi Ryan Dodson here today we're going to
talk about trapping in the wilderness
specifically in survival situations and
there's a lot of different trap options
that you have available to try and catch
yourself a meal there are pet traps that
you can dig there are deadfall traps you
can build but they take a lot of
calories and they're not as efficient as
snare traps snare traps are designed to
use cordage to catch your animal and
hold it in place until you can come over
and then dispatch of it and so the best
option is to actually have a
manufactured snare which is going to be
reinforced cable it's going to be an
eyelid at the end that's designed to be
stronger they can actually hold animals
as big as coyotes so that's your best
option unfortunately in survival
situations you rarely have that with you
and so what we're looking at using in
most cases is some kind of cordage so
I'm using just a orange 550 paracord
today so it's visible and you can see
how I tied the snare I prefer using
copper wire and I don't know how well
you can see this part of the reason why
I like using copper wire is because it
is hard to see the animals are not gonna
be able to see it nearly as easily and
so they're more likely to walk into your
trap when you're using wire the other
thing is you can bend and shape this
wire however you like and so it gives
you a lot of options as far as
positioning your snare that you don't
have with cordage that doesn't have that
stiffness to it the other thing is that
when you're tying wire versus cordage
you don't actually have to necessarily
tie anything you can just twist it like
a bread tie and in a lot of cases that's
going to be strong enough to hold when
you're dealing with an animal so those
are the advantages that I like you know
the spool that I use cost me I think
about 6 bucks it's a little spool of
wire like that and I've been using it
over and over and over again
I always carry this with me if at all
possible now as far as actually tying a
snare it's really pretty simple
you're gonna want to tie a simple
overhand knot in the end and then the
key to making sure that it does not slip
back open once the animal gets caught is
you're going to overlap it so if you can
see how I've overlapped right there and
then go through your two new eyelets to
create your snare if you can see how if
that looks right there that's gonna give
you twice as much tension on the line to
where when you catch an animal in here
it's not going to want to come loose
that is pretty tight right there so
that's how you want to tie your snares
whenever you're using cordage now unless
I'm trying to catch something big I'm
probably not going to use the full 5550
paracord this has a bunch of smaller
strands in the middle there that you can
pull out and each of those strands is
strong enough to catch an animal like a
rabbit or a squirrel so you can actually
make seven or eight different snares out
of a piece this size and that gets you
to be as efficient as possible so moving
back over to B wire here all we're gonna
do is make an eyelet
vbn back through the island and because
the wire retains its shape that much
better you really don't have to worry
about having the additional tension
because what's going to happen is as
this tightens down it's not gonna want
to bend and come loose it's gonna stay
in place and so that's one of the
reasons I really like using this wire
now as far as how you're going to attach
this snare and actually implement it in
the wild one of the easiest things to do
just take this end right here and tie it
onto something stationary whether that
be a stake in the ground or the base of
a tree or anything like that and then
you could position this in front of a
game trail just slightly up off the
ground so that as an animal comes
through here they're going to walk
through and get their head caught in the
snare and that's the quickest and
easiest way to use this another option
that I use all the time if I'm in a
wooded area where I know there's
squirrels is called a squirrel poll now
squirrels are fairly lazy if they have a
tree that they want to climb and they
have the option of climbing up another
pole that's resting against it or going
straight up and down they're always
going to take that 45-degree angle
because it just requires less energy so
by leaning the pole up against the tree
and putting stairs on that pole you give
yourself a very good opportunity to
catch that squirrel so I'm gonna go take
this and I'm gonna show you how I attach
it to a squirrel pole to be able to
catch squirrels in that manner
[Music]
okay so you can see that we've got these
snares attached and because of the
nature of the wire I'm able to position
them so they're just kind of floating
over the squirrel pole here so if we
want to attach a third one I usually
like three or four these on here we just
twist it a few times right there spin
this down around to the backside and
then put it up over top here and as the
squirrel goes up here he's going to
catch on one of these he's gonna fall
and he's gonna hang himself now we got
lunch okay so this is a spring snare
where I've actually used the spring pole
here along with importance and a
mechanism down here to hold it in place
this is just a stake and a stick right
here with the snare attached on the end
and so all I have to do take place the
snare and place him wherever I want it
that'll spring up and catch the end so
those are a few snare options for you to
help you get food in the wild
I'm Ryan Dotson thanks for watching
